member.name: T:Amazon.ControlTower.AmazonControlTowerDefaultConfiguration
member.summary: Configuration for accessing Amazon ControlTower service

member.name: M:Amazon.ControlTower.AmazonControlTowerDefaultConfiguration.GetAllConfigurations
member.summary: Collection of all s supported by ControlTower

summary.p: The STANDARD mode provides the latest recommended default values that should be safe to run in most scenarios
Note that the default values vended from this mode might change as best practices may evolve. As a result, it is encouraged to perform tests when upgrading the SDK
The IN_REGION mode builds on the standard mode and includes optimization tailored for applications which call AWS services from within the same AWS region
Note that the default values vended from this mode might change as best practices may evolve. As a result, it is encouraged to perform tests when upgrading the SDK
The CROSS_REGION mode builds on the standard mode and includes optimization tailored for applications which call AWS services in a different region
Note that the default values vended from this mode might change as best practices may evolve. As a result, it is encouraged to perform tests when upgrading the SDK
The MOBILE mode builds on the standard mode and includes optimization tailored for mobile applications
Note that the default values vended from this mode might change as best practices may evolve. As a result, it is encouraged to perform tests when upgrading the SDK
The AUTO mode is an experimental mode that builds on the standard mode. The SDK will attempt to discover the execution environment to determine the appropriate settings automatically.

Note that the auto detection is heuristics-based and does not guarantee 100% accuracy. STANDARD mode will be used if the execution environment cannot be determined. The auto detection might query EC2 Instance Metadata service, which might introduce latency. Therefore we recommend choosing an explicit defaults_mode instead if startup latency is critical to your application
The LEGACY mode provides default settings that vary per SDK and were used prior to establishment of defaults_mode

member.name: T:Amazon.ControlTower.Endpoints.ControlTowerEndpointParameters
member.summary: Contains parameters used for resolving ControlTower endpoints Parameters can be sourced from client config and service operations Used by internal ControlTowerEndpointProvider and ControlTowerEndpointResolver Can be used by custom EndpointProvider, see ClientConfig.EndpointProvider

member.name: T:Amazon.ControlTower.Internal.AmazonControlTowerEndpointProvider
member.summary: Amazon ControlTower endpoint provider. Resolves endpoint for given set of ControlTowerEndpointParameters. Can throw AmazonClientException if endpoint resolution is unsuccessful.

member.name: M:Amazon.ControlTower.Internal.AmazonControlTowerEndpointProvider.ResolveEndpoint(Amazon.Runtime.Endpoints.EndpointParameters)
member.summary: Resolve endpoint for ControlTowerEndpointParameters

member.name: T:Amazon.ControlTower.Internal.AmazonControlTowerEndpointResolver
member.summary: Amazon ControlTower endpoint resolver. Custom PipelineHandler responsible for resolving endpoint and setting authentication parameters for ControlTower service requests. Collects values for ControlTowerEndpointParameters and then tries to resolve endpoint by calling ResolveEndpoint method on GlobalEndpoints.Provider if present, otherwise uses ControlTowerEndpointProvider. Responsible for setting authentication and http headers provided by resolved endpoint.

member.name: T:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.ControlOperation
member.summary: An operation performed by the control.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.ControlOperation.EndTime
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property EndTime.
The time that the operation finished.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.ControlOperation.OperationType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OperationType.
One of ENABLE_CONTROL or DISABLE_CONTROL.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.ControlOperation.StartTime
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property StartTime.
The time that the operation began.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.ControlOperation.Status
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Status.
One of IN_PROGRESS, SUCEEDED, or FAILED.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.ControlOperation.StatusMessage
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property StatusMessage.
If the operation result is FAILED, this string contains a message explaining why the operation failed.

member.name: T:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.DisableControlRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the DisableControl operation. This API call turns off a control. It starts an asynchronous operation that deletes AWS resources on the specified organizational unit and the accounts it contains. The resources will vary according to the control that you specify.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.DisableControlRequest.ControlIdentifier
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ControlIdentifier.
The ARN of the control. Only Strongly recommended and Elective controls are permitted, with the exception of the Region deny guardrail.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.DisableControlRequest.TargetIdentifier
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TargetIdentifier.
The ARN of the organizational unit.

member.name: T:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.DisableControlResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the DisableControl operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.DisableControlResponse.OperationIdentifier
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OperationIdentifier.
The ID of the asynchronous operation, which is used to track status. The operation is available for 90 days.

member.name: T:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.EnableControlRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the EnableControl operation. This API call activates a control. It starts an asynchronous operation that creates AWS resources on the specified organizational unit and the accounts it contains. The resources created will vary according to the control that you specify.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.EnableControlRequest.ControlIdentifier
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ControlIdentifier.
The ARN of the control. Only Strongly recommended and Elective controls are permitted, with the exception of the Region deny guardrail.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.EnableControlRequest.TargetIdentifier
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TargetIdentifier.
The ARN of the organizational unit.

member.name: T:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.EnableControlResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the EnableControl operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.EnableControlResponse.OperationIdentifier
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OperationIdentifier.
The ID of the asynchronous operation, which is used to track status. The operation is available for 90 days.

member.name: T:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.EnabledControlSummary
member.summary: A summary of enabled controls.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.EnabledControlSummary.ControlIdentifier
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ControlIdentifier.
The ARN of the control. Only Strongly recommended and Elective controls are permitted, with the exception of the Region deny guardrail.

member.name: T:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.GetControlOperationRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the GetControlOperation operation. Returns the status of a particular EnableControl or DisableControl operation. Displays a message in case of error. Details for an operation are available for 90 days.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.GetControlOperationRequest.OperationIdentifier
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OperationIdentifier.
The ID of the asynchronous operation, which is used to track status. The operation is available for 90 days.

member.name: T:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.ListEnabledControlsRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the ListEnabledControls operation. Lists the controls enabled by AWS Control Tower on the specified organizational unit and the accounts it contains.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.ListEnabledControlsRequest.MaxResults
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxResults.
How many results to return per API call.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.ListEnabledControlsRequest.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
The token to continue the list from a previous API call with the same parameters.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.ListEnabledControlsRequest.TargetIdentifier
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TargetIdentifier.
The ARN of the organizational unit.

member.name: T:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.ListEnabledControlsResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the ListEnabledControls operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.ListEnabledControlsResponse.EnabledControls
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property EnabledControls.
Lists the controls enabled by AWS Control Tower on the specified organizational unit and the accounts it contains.

member.name: P:Amazon.ControlTower.Model.ListEnabledControlsResponse.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
Retrieves the next page of results. If the string is empty, the current response is the end of the results.

member.name: M:Amazon.ControlTower.AmazonControlTowerClient.#ctor
member.summary:
Constructs AmazonControlTowerClient with the credentials loaded from the application's default configuration, and if unsuccessful from the Instance Profile service on an EC2 instance.
Example App.config with credentials set.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>

member.name: M:Amazon.ControlTower.AmazonControlTowerClient.#ctor(Amazon.RegionEndpoint)
member.summary:
Constructs AmazonControlTowerClient with the credentials loaded from the application's default configuration, and if unsuccessful from the Instance Profile service on an EC2 instance.
Example App.config with credentials set.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>

member.name: M:Amazon.ControlTower.AmazonControlTowerClient.#ctor(Amazon.ControlTower.AmazonControlTowerConfig)
member.summary:
Constructs AmazonControlTowerClient with the credentials loaded from the application's default configuration, and if unsuccessful from the Instance Profile service on an EC2 instance.
Example App.config with credentials set.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>

member.name: M:Amazon.ControlTower.AmazonControlTowerClient.DisableControlAsync(Amazon.ControlTower.Model.DisableControlRequest,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: This API call turns off a control. It starts an asynchronous operation that deletes AWS resources on the specified organizational unit and the accounts it contains. The resources will vary according to the control that you specify.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the DisableControl service method.
A cancellation token that can be used by other objects or threads to receive notice of cancellation.
member.returns: The response from the DisableControl service method, as returned by ControlTower.
member.exception: User does not have sufficient access to perform this action.
Updating or deleting a resource can cause an inconsistent state.
Unexpected error during processing of request.
Request references a resource which does not exist.
Request would cause a service quota to be exceeded. The limit is 10 concurrent operations.
Request was denied due to request throttling.
The input fails to satisfy the constraints specified by an AWS service.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for DisableControl Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.ControlTower.AmazonControlTowerClient.EnableControlAsync(Amazon.ControlTower.Model.EnableControlRequest,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: This API call activates a control. It starts an asynchronous operation that creates AWS resources on the specified organizational unit and the accounts it contains. The resources created will vary according to the control that you specify.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the EnableControl service method.
A cancellation token that can be used by other objects or threads to receive notice of cancellation.
member.returns: The response from the EnableControl service method, as returned by ControlTower.
member.exception: User does not have sufficient access to perform this action.
Updating or deleting a resource can cause an inconsistent state.
Unexpected error during processing of request.
Request references a resource which does not exist.
Request would cause a service quota to be exceeded. The limit is 10 concurrent operations.
Request was denied due to request throttling.
The input fails to satisfy the constraints specified by an AWS service.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for EnableControl Operation
